G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified upon the showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The guidelines for custody and parenting plans emphasize stability for the child while fostering a meaningful relationship with both parents.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6 as the Middlesex County Probate and Family Court issued the original custody order dated May 14, 2019 (“Original Order”).

Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.raw_text: Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325 (2010)
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long held that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in determining custodial arrangements.
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in Massachusetts the best interests of the child are the overarching principle in custody disputes and cites prior Massachusetts cases and authorities to that effect. It also emphasizes that this best-interests inquiry is the controlling, child-centered standard and notes its historical roots, thereby affirming that Massachusetts courts have long treated the child’s best interests as paramount in determining custody. Thus, the case clearly supports the claimed proposition.
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003), and cases and authorities collected therein. ‘[T]he touchstone inquiry of what is “best for the child” is firmly rooted in American history, dating back to the Nineteenth Century.’ … In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long held that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in determining custodial arrangements.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody matters “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern,” and interprets the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests. It applies this standard in reviewing the custody award and removal order. This aligns with and affirms the long-standing Massachusetts principle that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in determining custodial arrangements.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’ Id. at 54.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Changes in a child’s developmental needs, educational requirements, and the improved circumstances of a parent constitute material and substantial changes justifying modification of a custody order.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address modification of an existing custody order based on changed circumstances such as a child’s developmental or educational needs or an improved parental situation. Instead, it deals with the proper criteria for an initial custody determination (or a custody decision on remand), emphasizing that all relevant factors must be weighed in terms of the child’s welfare. There is no discussion of ‘material and substantial change’ or of changes in needs/circumstances as a basis for modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Changes in a child’s developmental needs, educational requirements, and the improved circumstances of a parent constitute material and substantial changes justifying modification of a custody order.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a removal request and the ‘real advantage’/best interests analysis under Yannas and G.L. c. 208, § 30, not with a general standard for what constitutes a material and substantial change justifying modification of a custody order. While it does state that the mother’s remarriage is a material and substantial change in circumstances for purposes of modification under § 28, it does not address developmental or educational changes in the children, nor does it hold that those, combined with improved parental circumstances, constitute material and substantial changes. Thus the proposition is broader and different from what the case actually decides.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification. See Downey v. Downey, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815 (2002). In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The child’s age, expressed preferences, and the disruption caused by excessive transfers are relevant in determining the child’s best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly discusses best-interests factors (stability, work schedules, sibling relationships, and especially the harm from one parent’s alienating conduct and frequent moves), but it does not discuss the child’s age, the child’s own expressed preferences, or the disruption caused by excessive *transfers* between parents as separate analytical factors. The case focuses on disruption of attachment and instability from relocation and caregiving changes, not on the child’s stated wishes or the impact of frequent custody exchanges. Thus it does not cleanly support the specific proposition as phrased.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. … The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term…”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The child’s age, expressed preferences, and the disruption caused by excessive transfers are relevant in determining the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that custody and visitation decisions must be based on the children’s best interests, and mentions minimizing disruption, the primary nurturing parent, and the importance of the children’s environment. However, it does not discuss the children’s ages as a factor in itself, does not reference the children’s expressed preferences, and does not explicitly analyze disruption from excessive transfers or exchanges between parents. Thus, while generally consistent with best‑interests reasoning, it does not specifically establish the particular factors stated in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: The guidelines for custody and parenting plans emphasize stability for the child while fostering a meaningful relationship with both parents.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on child support calculations involving Social Security disability benefits, asset attachment, and the standard for modifying legal custody. It does not discuss guidelines for custody and parenting plans in terms that emphasize stability and fostering a meaningful relationship with both parents. The brief custody section refers only to best interests and the need for specific findings, not to any articulated guideline emphasizing stability or preserving relationships with both parents.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding “that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].” The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.

Stinson v. Meegan, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 302.raw_text: Stinson v. Meegan, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 302 (2004)
Stinson v. Meegan, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 302.proposition: Given Michael Smith’s stable living arrangement and the challenges caused by the current schedule, modification is necessary to avoid emotional and academic detriment to Jacob Smith.
Stinson v. Meegan, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 302.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landlord-tenant dispute, focusing on improper reliance on a housing specialist’s post-trial inspection and duplicative damages for habitability and quiet enjoyment. It does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or any analysis of how a child’s emotional or academic welfare justifies modification of a schedule. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about modifying arrangements based on a child’s detriment or a parent’s stable living arrangement.
Stinson v. Meegan, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 302.relevant_excerpt: In the instant case, there was no notice that an inspection would be conducted. There was no opportunity for the parties to challenge either the contents or the admissibility of the report or to examine the housing inspector. The judge’s reliance on the report was therefore in error.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Given Michael Smith’s stable living arrangement and the challenges caused by the current schedule, modification is necessary to avoid emotional and academic detriment to Jacob Smith.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying custody based on a parent’s stable living arrangement and the need to avoid emotional and academic detriment to a child. Ardizoni v. Raymond deals instead with whether separating twin siblings between two parents was proper and holds that there was no evidentiary basis that a split-custody arrangement was in their best interests. The opinion focuses on the presumption of keeping siblings together and the improper overreliance on children’s stated preferences, not on a rule that a stable home plus schedule-related challenges require modification to prevent emotional or academic harm.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “We have examined both the record from the proceedings below and the judge’s notes from his private interview with Rebecca and find no evidence from which the judge properly could have concluded that a split physical custody arrangement would be in the childrens’ best interests. Indeed, the evidence — including the opinions and recommendations of various witnesses (expert and nonexpert alike) plus the twins’ own reported statements about being separated from each other — is to the contrary.”
